snippet: With the lure of quick cash winnings, Japan’s industry around the game of pachinko — part pinball, part roulette — is trying to reinvent itself by appealing to new customers and by cleaning up its image.
abstract: Japan's once popular game of pachinko, facing decline, is trying to reinvent itself by appealing to new customers, mainly younger Japanese who grew up playing video and computer games; industry is also cleaning up its image as a haven for gangsters and an older generation of people; barely 10 million people played pachinko in 2013, compared to 30 million in 1990s.
lead_paragraph: With the lure of quick cash winnings, Japan’s industry around the game of pachinko — part pinball, part roulette — is trying to reinvent itself by appealing to new customers and by cleaning up its image.

headline.main: To Draw in New Crowds, an Industry Bets on Itself
headline.print_headline: To Draw In New Crowds, an Industry Bets on Itself
